title: How to Make an Activity Jar

steps.headline: Pick up your supplies.
steps.description: You need a Mason jar (or any jar), paper, scissors and pens.

steps.headline: Write on the strips.
steps.description:
Write down activities that you enjoy doing and that help to keep you busy. The idea is to spark your motivation when you don't feel it. Ideas include:
Kitchen activities: Cooking, baking, making chocolates or candies, making gift cookies, making Marzipan models, etc. Living room activities: Watching movies or TV shows, doing a jigsaw puzzle, playing on the iPad, playing music, etc. Quiet activities: Reading a book, writing poems, taking a nap, deep thinking, etc. Outdoor activities: Playing sport, going for a run, riding the bike, walking the dog, clearing the yard, etc.

steps.headline: Fold up the strips.
steps.description: Once they're small cubes, pop them into the jar.

steps.headline: Label the jar.
steps.description: Write "Bored Jar" on a small piece of paper, and tape/glue it on the jar.

steps.headline: Collect your supplies.
steps.description: You'll need a Mason jar or any jar, various pictures printed off the internet, pencil and paper.

steps.headline: Put the pictures in the jar.
Play the Pictionary game with friends.
steps.description: Pick a picture from the jar and write down on pieces of paper what you think the picture represents.

steps.headline: Choose your supplies.
steps.description: You'll need a jar, paper, pens.

steps.headline: Write on each strip the name of a person, object or activity.
steps.description: Put the strips in the jar.

steps.headline: Play a guessing game with your friends.
steps.description: One player draws a strip of paper, and the other players try to guess what is written on the strip. The questions must be answered only with a "yes" or "no."

steps.headline: Make up a jar for keeping on a shelf.
steps.description: Choose a pretty jar, as it's on display.

steps.headline: Tear up or cut out a bunch of paper strips.
steps.description: Keep them near the jar, with a pen.

steps.headline: Write down good memories from each day on the strips of paper.
steps.description: Add them to the jar. Adding a date is optional but may be something you'd like to do.

steps.headline: Keep this up for as long as you wish.
steps.description: On days when you feel bored, nostalgic or need a boost, pull some memories from the jar to remind yourself of the great things you've done and feelings you've experienced in the past.

text:
Bored Jar Pick up your supplies. You need a Mason jar (or any jar), paper, scissors and pens. Cut long strips of paper.  Write on the strips. Write down activities that you enjoy doing and that help to keep you busy. The idea is to spark your motivation when you don't feel it. Ideas include:
Kitchen activities: Cooking, baking, making chocolates or candies, making gift cookies, making Marzipan models, etc. Living room activities: Watching movies or TV shows, doing a jigsaw puzzle, playing on the iPad, playing music, etc. Quiet activities: Reading a book, writing poems, taking a nap, deep thinking, etc. Outdoor activities: Playing sport, going for a run, riding the bike, walking the dog, clearing the yard, etc. Fold up the strips. Once they're small cubes, pop them into the jar. Label the jar. Write "Bored Jar" on a small piece of paper, and tape/glue it on the jar. Pictionary Jar Collect your supplies. You'll need a Mason jar or any jar, various pictures printed off the internet, pencil and paper. Put the pictures in the jar.  Play the Pictionary game with friends. Pick a picture from the jar and write down on pieces of paper what you think the picture represents. Guessing Jar Choose your supplies. You'll need a jar, paper, pens. Cut out strips of paper.  Write on each strip the name of a person, object or activity. Put the strips in the jar. Play a guessing game with your friends. One player draws a strip of paper, and the other players try to guess what is written on the strip. The questions must be answered only with a "yes" or "no." Memory Jar Make up a jar for keeping on a shelf. Choose a pretty jar, as it's on display. Tear up or cut out a bunch of paper strips. Keep them near the jar, with a pen. Write down good memories from each day on the strips of paper. Add them to the jar. Adding a date is optional but may be something you'd like to do. Keep this up for as long as you wish. On days when you feel bored, nostalgic or need a boost, pull some memories from the jar to remind yourself of the great things you've done and feelings you've experienced in the past.
